As the Government has made special grants for beef roads in Queensland and for harbour and dam construction works in Western Australia since the proposals to mitigate flood damage on the Clarence River were advanced, will the Government use the same constitutional power that validated those grants to validate the assistance sought by the State of New South Wales and the Clarence River County Council Flood Mitigation Authority on a basis of one-third Commonwealth contribution and two-thirds State contribution?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.label: 1 and 2.
item.para: The request to which the honorable member refers was made in 1960, when the Premier of New South Wales wrote to the Prime Minister asking the Commonwealth to assist, on a Â£l-for-Â£l basis, in financing a number of flood mitigation projects, includng works estimated to cost Â£1,500,000 in the Clarence River area. The Government did not agree to provide the assistance requested because, under the constitutional division of responsibilities, the planning, financing and carrying out of flood prevention works fall within the province of State governments and their authorities. The provision of additional finance to expedite a programme of flood mitigation and control in a State is a matter for consideration by the State government concerned in the light of its overall financial position and other relevant circumstances. Requests for assistance with such projects have been received from time to time from various State governments, but they have without exception been declined for the foregong reasons. The Commonwealth Government is by no means unmindful of the fact that many State works (including works such as flood control) are of great importance in conserving and developing the nation's resources. Primarily for this reason the Commonwealth has, in recent years, assisted the Loan Council borrowing programme on a large scale. Since 1951-52 when the Commonwealth first supported the Loan Council borrowing programmes, the amount of Â£2,036,000,000 has become available for the works programmes of the States, and Â£790,000,000 of this has been provided by the Commonwealth from its own resources. In arranging this special assistance the Commonwealth Government decided that it should assist the State loan programmes as a whole rather than finance particular projects, and thus leave the State governments free to decide on the particular works which should be undertaken. The Commonwealth, therefore, has been and still is taking action to ensure that the maximum practicable amounts are available for the financing of State works projects as a whole. The distribution among States of the overall amount of finance available for this purpose is, of course, determined by the Loan Council, but as mentioned above the projects to which a State applies its share are decided by that State. It is true that, in addition to its support of Loan Council borrowing programmes, the Commonwealth has agreed to provide special financial assistance for certain works projects in the States. There have been special reasons in each case for the provision of this addtional assistance. Of the projects referred to by the honorable member, the assistance provided in respect of beef cattle roads in Queensland is for the specific purpose of encouraging a greater flow of exports in the national interest. The assistance in respect of harbour and dam construction works in Western Australia is provided under the authority of the Western Australia Grant (Northern Development) Act for the purpose of assisting development undertaken by the State in that part of the State north of the twentieth parallel of latitude.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice -

quote.para: Does he propose to remove the Â£2,750 limit which he fixed on 9th January, 1960, on housing loans to individuals by the Commonwealth Trading Bank or the Commonwealth Savings Bank?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honorable member's question is as follows: -

quote.para: The Commonwealth Banking Corporation Board periodically reviews the maximum amount of individual credit foncier loans made by the Commonwealth Savings Bank for housing purposes under Part VI. of the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959-1962. In making these reviews, the Board takes into account the funds available to the Bank for such loans, the extent of the demand on the bank for such loans and other relevant circumstances.

As a result of a recent review by the Board, the maximum amount of a credit foncier loan was raised last February from Â£2,500 to Â£2,750, which happens to be the maximum amount at present prescribed under the Commonwealth Banks Regulations. This was the extent of the increase which the board, after full consideration of the factors referred to above, felt to be practicable for the time being.

answer.para: It needs to be appreciated, of course, that the funds available to the Commonwealth Savings Bank for credit foncier housing loans ate not unlimited. An increase in the amount of individual loans must, unless it is accompanied by an increase in the amount of funds available for such loans, mean a corresponding reduction in the number of loans the bank can make. The board has, therefore, to strike a balance between the objectives of assisting the greatest practicable number of the bank's customers to obtain homes and of pitching the maximum individual amount at the highest practicable level.

The board would like to be able to raise further the increased maximum individual amount it fixed last February. However, it naturally wishes to examine the effects of the increase to Â£2,750 before considering further action. If as a result of experience in regard to the present maximum of Â£2,750, the board felt it could increase the maximum further, the Government would sympathetically consider the question of increasing the present limit to Â£2,750 under the Commonwealth Banks Regulations.

Although Part VI. of the Commonwealth Banks Act, which provides for the making of housing loans on special terms, formally applies to the Commonwealth Trading Bank as well as to the Commonwealth Savings Bank, all such business is in practice undertaken by the Commonwealth Savings Bank. The Commonwealth Trading Bank does, however, provide some housing finance on an ordinary overdraft basis and the limit of Â£2,750 does not apply to this lending.

talk.start.para: n asked the Treasurer, upon notice -

item.para: Is it likely that Australia will adopt a decimal system of coinage?
Would this require a large issue of new coins?
Would the existing mints in Melbourne and Perth be unable to cope with the job?
If so, what are the reasons for the inability of these mints to expand their capacity?
Have proposals been considered for the establishment in Canberra of a mint equipped with American machinery?
Would this involve a net cost of dollar balances and result in the production of coins of American size and weight?
Would this involve the obsolescence of existing parking meters, slot machines and telephone appliances and their replacement by American-produced meters, machines and appliances?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: The Government has on a number of occasions affirmed its support in principle for a system of decimal currency, but it has not yet decided upon a precise time-table for a changeover, nor on the procedures which would have to be adopted prior to the changeover date.

item.label: 2, 3 and 4.
item.para: If a system of decimal currency were introduced into Australia, a very large number of new coins would need to be available by the changeover date, or very shortly afterwards, in order to ensure that any inconvenience caused to the public would be reduced to the barest minimum. The two Mints situated in Melbourne and Perth are the only remaining oversea branches of the Royal Mint, London, but the buildings and equipment are owned by the Governments of Victoria and Western Australia, respectively. Subject to the limitations imposed by some of the out-of-date equipment installed, both mints are efficiently operated but they would be incapable of producing the requisite number of new decimal coins on an economical basis and within an acceptably short period. It has been decided that the only practicable method of overcoming the problem of replacing every coin at present in circulation while at the same time providing for the increasing annual requirements of an expanding population, would be to establish a new national mint centrally placed in Canberra and equipped with modern machinery suitable for large-scale production techniques. This machinery is such that a single installation would be adequate for Australian requirements for many years to come, and it would not be practicable to equip one or other of the two present mints (neither of which is in any case under Commonwealth control) with new machinery of this type, without a major reconstruction and extension of the buildings well beyond the limits of their existing sites.

It is expected that tenders will be called in due course, in Australia and overseas, for most items of equipment to be installed in the National Mint. While some of the equipment has not been produced in Australia so far, it is expected that Australian manufacturers will be able to tender for the majority of the items. The United States of America is only one of several countries from which tenders may be expected for items which cannot be produced in Australia at competitive prices. Each tender will be examined in accordance with normal practice, and no decision has been taken that a specific item of equipment will be purchased from a particular country.

item.label: 6 and 7.
item.para: No final decision has been taken on the precise sizes and weights which new decimal coins would have, but the Government has no intention that they should necessarily be identical in size and weight with the coins of any particular country. A great deal of consideration will need to be given to such matters in due course.

subdebateinfo.title: Assistance to Primary Producers in Queensland.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice -

item.para: Has his attention been drawn to the serious plight of primary producers in central Queensland who are still suffering from the effects of a prolonged and disastrous drought?

If so, can he say whether many of these producers, owing to the adverse conditions and uncertain state of marketing and prices, and in an effort to improve their conditions by diversifying their farming activity, have been forced to make extensive purchases of additional machinery on hire purchase the payments for which, under the circumstances, they now find serious difficulty in meeting?
Will the Government consider proclaiming a moratorium to give temporary relief to these and any other primary producers in similar circumstances?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: For some years the monsoonal rain influences which are so important to primary production in Queensland have not fully benefited many parts of the State, including the area represented by the honorable member for Capricornia. The patchy and spasmodic nature of the rainfall has had an adverse effect on primary production, particularly on crop production, but I have not been informed that primary producers in central Queensland are in serious difficulties, nor has the Government been approached for any form of relief. The provision of drought relief within a State is of course primarily a matter for the State Government.

Information available to my department indicates that hire purchase debts represent a comparatively low proportion of total farm borrowings in central Queensland. It is appreciated that this is a broad picture and that in individual cases difficulties might well be experienced in meeting hire purchase payments. However, I am not aware that these difficulties are as widespread and serious as has been suggested by the honorable member.
Any measure to provide relief from debt by way of moratorium or otherwise on a regional basis within a State is a matter for the State government concerned.
